abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, although its sustainability is unlikely,
            unless new Federal funding mechanisms are developed, or
            priorities changed at the provincial level. Among the many
            lessons learned, and in the context of financial
            sustainability, political priorities should have taken
            place, to reflect ownership of the program by health sector
            leaders, emphasizing, at the provincial ministries level,
            institutional arrangements for the execution, operation, and
            expansion of the program, an emphasis which would have
            forced a resolution to the issue of institutional isolation
            of child development activities, long before the end of the
            project. Regarding investments, and although Argentina is
            among the region's richest nations, the health sector
            remains in a poor state of physical, and technical
            development; thus investments in civil work, equipment, and
            training have not been enough to infuse changes in the
            culture of health care provision. Rather, project design
            should have focused on a long-term health system, aligning
            organization, and financing to achieve results in response
            to demand, and partly, in a reform-oriented vision.
            Monitoring, and evaluation should have been strengthened,
            considering that the knowledge output of the project, was as
            important as physical outputs, and, structuring financing,
            but contingent on producing monitoring data.
